titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the Edison Cylinder Collection, 1902-1916 CAM.EDI.1982.01
titlestmt.author: Melanie Root.

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on 2024-07-08 17:27:39 -0400.
profiledesc.langusage: Description is written in: English, Latin script.

did.abstract: The Edison Cylinder Collection represents both the songs and the sound recording technology of the late nineteenth and early twentieth centuries. The songs range from Christmas tunes to Stephen Foster melodies and showcase American Popular Music through Thomas Edison's innovations.

userestrict.head: Copyright
userestrict.p: The Center for American Music at the University of Pittsburgh assumes copyright for all materials in this collection. Any reproduction or new work derived from the materials in this collection will have to be authorized by the University and the Center for American Music.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: This collection is largely unprocessed and unorganized. A preservation survey has been conducted by Melanie Root in 2010 in order to determine which cylinders to keep in the collection, which can be salvaged and preserved, and which have to be deaccessioned.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Edison Cylinder Collection, 1902-1915, CAM.EDI.1982.1, Center for American Music, University of Pittsburgh

accessrestrict.head: Access Restrictions
accessrestrict.p: There are no content restrictions for this collection. However, due to the nature of the material, the cylinders are to be handled in a very precise way. They should not be held from the outside, but rather two fingers should be inserted into the core of the cylinder then separated to hold the cylinder in place while handling. The oils and rubbing from touching the outside of the cylinder can do damage to the recording grooves in the wax or Amberol.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: This collection consists of 78 sound recording Edison cylinders. The majority of the cylinders (55) are formatted on Blue Amberol cylinders. Also included are black wax cylinders (13), grey wax cylinders (2), and a purple Amberol cylinder. There are also six cylinders of unknown formats either due to their strange coloring and material, or to their fragility and thus were not able to be removed from their cases.

These cylinders showcase sound recordings from the first decades of the twentieth century. Included are Christmas tunes, instrumental arrangements of popular parlor songs, dances, and a basic selection of Popular American music from between 1902-1916.

bioghist.head: History
bioghist.p: By speaking the words "Mary had a little lamb," Thomas Edison successfully created the first cylinder sound recording in 1877 using tin foil as the recording medium. A stylus created grooves in the medium that corresponded to sound. This technique is not unlike modern vinyl records and LP's. However, Edison discovered that tin foil was not very durable and often only lasted through one or two playbacks. In the decade before the twentieth century, a switch to soft brown wax was made in the hopes that this material would outlast the tin foil as a recording medium for the spoken word as well as vocal and instrumental music.

When the brown wax proved to be almost as problematic to maintain as the tin foil, Edison switched to black wax in 1902. These black wax cylinders were slightly more durable then their brown wax relatives. They also allowed for standardization of rotations per minute in playback speed making most of the Edison cylinders two minutes in recorded length.

Soon after the wax cylinders became popular, another Edison innovation came about in the form of plastic cellulose. This substance, most commonly referred to in the cylinders as Amberol, proved to be even more durable than the wax cylinders. The most popular version used by Edison was the Blue Amberol cylinder. This consists of a plastic cellulose cylinder with a plaster core. These, along with the wax cylinders, were played on special rotating cylinder phonographs that were able to read the peaks and valleys with a needle, like a modern record player.

With the emergence of the recorded disc, the Edison Cylinders fell out of vogue and were not made after the mid-1910s. Today, the Library of Congress pays special attention to their brown wax cylinders because of the cylinders extreme fragility. Of the surviving formats, these are most at risk of being lost forever. The next most vulnerable are the black wax followed by the Amberol. While both the black wax and Amberol are not as susceptible to mold and temperature fluctuation damage as the brown wax cylinders, they still require special care and housing to maintain their playability.

The Edison Cylinder Collection was gifted to the Center for American Music by its current director, Dr. Deane L. Root. The cylinders were collected by Dr. Root's uncle who had an affinity for old sound recordings. The Center for American Music accepted the gift due to the relevance of the recordings and their historic and research value to the University of Pittsburgh. The cylinders are currently housed in the archive where light, temperature, and humidity can be monitored and controlled.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: This collection was left in its original order in the specialized case as well as on the top shelf of the audio case. Because of this decision, there are no series or sections intellectually describing the cylinders in the finding aid.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: This is a Blue Amberol Edison Cylinder. The printed ID number on the rim reads 1532. The performer is Van Eps. The inside plaster core is chipped on the edges. The cylinder is in the wrong case. The case lid reads, "California and You (Harry Puck) performed by Billy Murray and Chorus."
This cylinder has been digitized by US Santa Barbara and can be streamed or downloaded here: http://cylinders.library.ucsb.edu/search.php?queryType=@attr+1=1020&num=1&start=1&query=cylinder634

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: This item is a Black Wax Edison Cylinder recording. The printed ID number on the rim of the cylinder is illegible. There is a long thin scratch lengthwise across the cylinder. It is not in its original case. The case lid reads "Down where the Swanee River Flows performed by George Wilton Ballard and Chorus." A handwritten label is attached to the case which reads "Carry Me Back to Virginia."

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: This is a Black Wax Edison Cylinder recording. The ID number printed on the cylinder is 913. The performer is printed as Stewart. There is a small crack in the wax about 1 centimeter long from the bottom lip of the cylinder. It is not in a case.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: This is a Blue Amberol Edison Cylinder recording. The printed ID number is 4003. The performer is printed as Louise Terrell and C. Ballard. There is a small accretion stuck to the plastic cellulose. It is in its original case, however, the lid is coming apart.

This cylinder has been digitized by UC Santa Barbara and can be streamed here: http://cylinders.library.ucsb.edu/search.php?queryType=@attr%201=4&query=don%27t+you+remember+the+time&num=1&start=1&sortBy=&sortOrder=id

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: This is a Blue Amberol Edison Cylinder recording. Its ID number is printed as 1539. The performer is printed as NY Military Band. There is a small amount of discoloration on the bottom lip of the cylinder. The inner plaster core is cracked and pitted on the edges. The cylinder is in the wrong case. The case lid reads "Climbing Up de Golden Stairs performed by Walter van Brunt and Chorus."
This cylinder has been digitized by UC Santa Barbara and may be streamed here: http://cylinders.library.ucsb.edu/search.php?queryType=@attr+1=1020&num=1&start=1&query=cylinder7251

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: This is a Blue Amberol Edison Cylinder recording. Its printed ID number is 2950. The performer is printed as Jaudas' Society Orchestra. There is some mold near the lip of the inner plaster core as well as some minor pitting ad cracking of the core. The cylinder is in the wrong case. The case lid reads "She Said 'Aloha' to Me Performed by Walter van Brunt and Chorus."
This cylinder has been digitized by UC Santa Barbara and may be streamed here: http://cylinders.library.ucsb.edu/search.php?queryType=@attr+1=1020&num=1&start=1&query=cylinder492

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: This is a Blue Amberol Edison Cylinder recording. Its printed ID number is 1971. The performer is printed as Jones and L. Spencer. There is some moderate mold on the plaster core as well as some pitting and cracking at the edges. Several small cracks appear in the plastic cellulose at the bottom lip of the cylinder. The cylinder is in the wrong case. The case lid reads "Oh! How She Could Yacki Hacki Wicki Wacki Woo (That's Love in Honolulu) performed by Arthur Collins and Byron G. Harlan." There is a handwritten label attached to the lid which reads "Peaches and Cream."
This cylinder has been digitzed by UC Santa Barbara and may be streamed here: http://cylinders.library.ucsb.edu/search.php?queryType=@attr+1=1020&num=1&start=1&query=cylinder492

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: This is a Blue Amberol Edison Cylinder recording. Its condition is unknown due to the inability to safely remove it from its case. There is severe damage to the bottom of the case which may contribute to this situation.
This cylinder has been digitzed by Syracuse University and may be heard here: http://digilib.syr.edu/cdm4/item_viewer.php?CISOROOT=/cylinder&CISOPTR=686&CISOBOX=1&REC=13

scopecontent.p: This is a Black Wax Edison cylinder sound recording. The ID number is printed as 9423. There is no performer printed on the cylinder. There is severe pitting and loss to the wax playing surface on a large portion of the cylinder. The inner core is severely dirty. The cylinder is unplayable. It is in a case with no lid.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: This is a Blue Amberol Edison cylinder sound recording. The performer and ID number are printed as Knickerbocker Quartet, 1557. There is some very slight browning of the plastic on the top rim. The cylinder is in the wrong case. The case has no lid. The cylinder could not be transferred to the correct case as that case cannot be safely removed from another cylinder.
This cylinder has been digitized by UC Santa Barbara and may be streamed here: http://cylinders.library.ucsb.edu/search.php?queryType=@attr+1=1020&num=1&start=1&query=cylinder641

scopecontent.p: This is a Blue Amberol Edison cylinder sound recording. The performer and ID number are listed as, Rodeheaver, 2354. There is some very slight pitting to the bottom edge of the inner plaster core. There are also some slight cracks to the bottom edge of the plastic. The plastic is also lightening around the edges. The cylinder is in its original case.
This cylinder has been digitized by UC Santa Barbara and may be streamed here: http://cylinders.library.ucsb.edu/search.php?queryType=@attr+1=1020&num=1&start=1&query=cylinder155

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes

There is some very slight pitting to the inner plaster core. There are also some moderate dirt accretions to the plastic in places. The case has no lid.

The performer and title of the cylinder could not be found on the pieces. The cylinder is unplayable. The case lid reads, "Old Folks at Home."

The case has no lid or bottom. No writing is printed on the rims of the cylinder so the title, performer and ID number are unknown. The cylinder is unplayable.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: This is a Black Wax Edison cylinder sound recording. The performer and most of the ID number are illegible. There is severe mold damage and discoloration to a large portion of the wax surface. There is also a large vertical crack through the wax as well as a piece missing from the top of the cylinder. The cylinder is in the wrong case. The lid reads, "What's the [?]i[?]se."
This cylinder has been digitized by UC Santa Barbara and may be downloaded or streamed here: http://cylinders.library.ucsb.edu/search.php?queryType=@attr+1=1020&num=1&start=1&query=cylinder1615

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: This is a Grey Wax Edison cylinder sound recording. The performer and ID number are not visibly printed on the wax. Mold damage covers almost the entire surface of the cylinder. Tape has been applied to the bottom of the case to act as support for the cylinder inside. There is no lid.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: This is a Purple Amberol Edison cylinder sound recording. The performer and ID number are printed as, Anna Case & Criterion Quartet, 29022. There are some small scratches and rub marks to the plastic. The case has no lid. The cylinder is in its original case.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: This is a Grey Wax Edison cylinder sound recording. The performer, title, and ID number are not visibly printed on the wax. The surface of the wax is completely obscured by mold damage. The case has no lid or bottom. Tape has been placed on the bottom of the case to support the cylinder inside.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes

This cylinder has been digitized by UC Santa Barbara and may be downloaded or streamed here: http://cylinders.library.ucsb.edu/search.php?queryType=@attr+1=1020&num=1&start=1&query=cylinder2725
